## Perlin.fractalNoise3d() method

Generate a three-dimensional FBM.

**Signature:**

```typescript
fractalNoise3d(x: number, y: number, z: number, options?: FractalOptions3D): number;
```

## Parameters

<table><thead><tr><th>

Parameter


</th><th>

Type


</th><th>

Description


</th></tr></thead>
<tbody><tr><td>

x


</td><td>

number


</td><td>

The position on the x-axis for generating three-dimensional FBM.


</td></tr>
<tr><td>

y


</td><td>

number


</td><td>

The position on the y-axis for generating three-dimensional FBM.


</td></tr>
<tr><td>

z


</td><td>

number


</td><td>

The position on the z-axis for generating three-dimensional FBM.


</td></tr>
<tr><td>

options


</td><td>

[FractalOptions3D](./perlin.ts.fractaloptions3d.md)


</td><td>

_(Optional)_ The configuration of the FBM, See [FractalOptions3D](./perlin.ts.fractaloptions3d.md) for more.


</td></tr>
</tbody></table>
**Returns:**

number

The normalized noise value, with a range from -1 to 1.

## Remarks

Fractal noise realizes more intricate details by overlaying various noise layers of distinct frequencies and amplitudes, making it applicable for scenarios that demand multi-scale detail like the creation of natural landscapes.

## Example


```typescript
const perlin:Perlin = new Perlin();

// The basic case
perlin.fractalNoise3d(0.5, 0.5, 0.5);

// The advanced case
const options:FractalOptions3D = {
  octaves: 5,
  amplitude: 1.0,
  persistence: 1.5,
  frequency: {x: 0.001, y: 0.001, z: 0.001},
  lacunarity: {x: 2.0, y: 2.0, z: 2.0},
  offset: {x: 21.0, y: 22.0, z: 23.0},
}
perlin.fractalNoise3d(10, 11, 12, options);
```
